Award.AwardTitle: Building Capacity to Produce STEM Teachers at a Hispanic Serving Institution in Illinois

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to serve the national need to increase the number of qualified secondary STEM teachers, including the number of Hispanic STEM teachers in high-needs school districts. Increased participation of Hispanic students in STEM secondary education majors will help address the national and local need for culturally responsive, bilingual teachers. These teachers will also also serve as role models to help all secondary students envision themselves in STEM teaching careers. The project team will develop and implement survey instruments for high school and college students who are majoring in STEM. Data collected from the surveys will be used to develop effective mechanisms for increasing awareness of STEM teaching licensure as a career path and help to identify opportunities to help students pursuing and attaining licensure. The implementation of professional development speakers and faculty workshops on culturally relevant teaching will help faculty encourage underrepresented students to pursue this pathway. These activities are expected to increase institutional capacity for the recruitment and support of students in the secondary STEM education program.

This project at Aurora University includes partnerships with the East Aurora and West Aurora School Districts and Elgin Community College. Project goals are to identify methods to connect students to careers in STEM secondary education, establish the foundation for a strong pipeline of STEM secondary teacher candidates from area high schools and community colleges, and to develop the infrastructure for a subsequent Robert Noyce Track I Scholarships and Stipends program. Replicable survey and focus group instruments will enable other institutions to adapt and implement these tools to better increase their own STEM education licensure enrollment and allow high school faculty to address barriers earlier in the education process, when many students are formulating career perceptions. An independent evaluation of this program will include focus groups, interviews, and document reviews combined with quantitative/direct data from program activities to measure achieved outcomes, challenges, and impact of the project. Results from this program will be disseminated on the project website, at campus events and meetings, to area high schools and colleges, and will be presented at the annual NSF Noyce Summit as well as at regional and national conferences. This Capacity Building project is supported through the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program (Noyce). The Noyce program supports talented STEM undergraduate majors and professionals to become effective K-12 STEM teachers and experienced, exemplary K-12 STEM teachers to become STEM master teachers in high-need school districts. It also supports research on the persistence, retention, and effectiveness of K-12 STEM teachers in high-need school districts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Aurora University?s NSF Noyce Capacity Building Project titled, Building Capacity to Produce STEM Teachers at a Hispanic Serving Institution in Illinois, was proposed with our partner school districts, East Aurora SD131 and West Aurora SD129, to build the foundation for a subsequent Robert Noyce Track 1 Scholarships and Stipends at AU, which would increase the number of highly qualified Hispanic STEM teachers. The major goals of the Capacity Building project were to: 1) establish a new mechanism to promote collaboration and coordination among STEM Education stakeholders, 2) increase recruitment of High School/Transfer students and AU STEM majors into STEM education tracks, and 3) create new programming for faculty to promote STEM education as a career option. The grant activities were successfully completed during a very challenging pandemic period.

To establish an effective partnership between STEM stakeholders, a STEM Advisory Panel was created with members from school district educators, community college recruiting staff, university enrollment, and university faculty. The members finalized the scope and responsibilities of the STEM Advisory Panel. Two virtual meetings were held during the grant period and the panel was kept informed about grant activities via email. The panel provided insightful information on student barriers to STEM, recruitment, and misconceptions of teaching careers. This unique format allowed to build critical relationships for continued collaborations between members of the panel.

Different strategies were implemented to increase recruitment of students into STEM education. Surveys were administered to all freshmen for a deeper understanding of their perceptions of STEM teaching as a career. The analysis of the survey data was used in the development of marketing materials for AU?s secondary education programs. The project team collaborated with high school STEM teachers to create virtual lesson plans for high school students and developed a STEM education club, Gold Mine, modeled after the Educators Rising club. In addition, the team collaborated with community college faculty to pilot a workshop, Building Curiosity and Wonder of Science, for community college students. These activities will allow for future collaborations and extend university outreach to high school as well as community college students.

To improve pathways for AU STEM freshman and sophomores into STEM education, AU-SSM (AU STEM Success Matters) workshops were held virtually for all STEM majors. This event involved all STEM faculty and Academic Support Center which offers tutoring services. Session topics included themes such as technology, STEM skills, and careers. The career session included presentations on careers in high school STEM teaching. The average satisfaction score was 3.4 out of 4.0. Another strategy to expose current STEM students to teaching careers was via a hands-on project in Calculus I course. Students in the course created hands-on demonstrations of Calculus applications for 8th graders.

Faculty and staff perceptions of STEM education were collected via a survey and a focus group to get insights such as understanding of their roles and requiring resources on how to engage students to pursue education careers. The grant team coordinated a university faculty development virtual workshop, Culturally Relevant and Responsive Teaching and Learning with Latinx students, to provide a culturally relevant pedagogy foundations and strategies. Additional STEM focused professional learning sessions allowed STEM faculty to create and implement culturally relevant lessons. The grant team coordinated a workshop, Growing our profession: Cultivating culturally responsive STEM educators, for high school teachers.

A significant outcome of this grant was that the university established programs such as Master of Arts in Teaching and chemistry secondary education. Marketing flyers were developed to promote STEM education programs and distributed to university faculty. University wide STEM events will include STEM education and invite high school educators to be part of career panel. STEM faculty have deeply embraced the culturally relevant pedagogical practices into their teaching as a result of several faculty development workshops.

The grant team has presented at several conferences and will continue to disseminate the information learned from the project. During the grant period, the team presented two poster presentations at the American Chemical Society Spring Virtual conference and two oral presentations at the 2021 Midwest Annual Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship program conference. The results of the grant surveys were shared with the STEM Advisory Panel. The Panel will continue to meet in subsequent years to continue to identify strategies to recruit students in STEM education.

The Noyce Capacity Building grant has allowed the grant team to build collaborations and working relationships between the university faculty, school districts, and community colleges. The faculty have learned how to engage and motivate Latinx students in STEM. These initiatives will provide a solid foundation to submit a Track 1 Scholarship and Stipend grant to prepare future STEM teachers.
